course_title: Applied Research in Criminology and Criminal Justice 2

learning_outcomes.description: Critically understand the rationale and processes for the collection, coding and analysis of qualitative and quantitative data
Demonstrate ability to conduct data analyses relevant to your research questions and aims

assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, Students will reflect on their own skills, knowledge and attributes as they respond to a sample CJS related position description.

Students will provide a 2-page Professional Resume that targets the position criteria and participate in an in-class mock interview for the position. Through the Professional Resume and Interview, students will articulate their professional identity and provide evidence of their suitability to the position. Further task details and requirements (including relevant marking criteria) can be found in the relevant Assessment folder on Blackboard. 

Submission: This assessment includes an in-person practical (mock interview and pitch) and two-page resume. You must attend your mock interview at the scheduled rostered time. You may refer to your resume during the interview. You must submit your resume electronically by the due time, on the due date. Your assignment must be submitted via Turnitin on Blackboard. By uploading your assignment via Turnitin, you are certifying that the work you submit is your own work except where correctly attributed to another source (including AI). Please see JAC for more submission information.

Please note that the Methods Defence is an individual in-person assessment. The Methods Defence will be conducted in-person during regular class hours. The rostered time will be posted the week of the Methods Defence.
assessments.task_description:
The Methods Defence Assessment is an opportunity for students to individually demonstrate their understanding of research methods and respective analytic approaches to their current research projects. This task aims to strengthen capability to effectively engage with both qualitative and quantitative research methods by the conclusion of the course.

In this in-person individual practical, students will demonstrate critical understanding of their methodological choices through structured questioning that explores rationale, implementation, analysis, and limitations. The assessment also requires students to articulate complex methodological concepts and justify decisions against alternatives while acknowledging methodological constraints.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use notes, successful completion of this assessment will require students to understand their methods and critically engage in a discussion about their project aims, methodological approach (including limitations, benefits and feasibility) and an exploration of alternative methods.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assignment is an individual in-person assessment. Students are not required to submit work to Blackboard for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
The Research Showcase is an opportunity for students to disseminate research evidence to industry, staff and peers. Students will use their research report and activities as the foundation for their presentation and 2-page research brief/executive summary to convey the key elements of their research including their research problem, aims and questions, methods, results, and conclusions. The presentation and brief should be visually engaging and demonstrate expertise in the topic area. Both the presentation and brief should communicate content clearly and appropriately for a non-specialist audience and use persuasive language that conveys the significance of the research and research findings. Further task details and requirements (including relevant marking criteria) can be found in the relevant Assessment folder on blackboard. 

Please ensure that all sources are authentic and appropriately evidenced in the brief and presentation, including the use of AI.

SUBMISSION: Research Showcase Presentations will occur during class time in Week 13. You must submit your PowerPoint and Brief by 10am on Thursday 30 October to enable consolidation (PowerPoints) and printing (briefs). Presentation and Brief will be presented/provided during class; Your FINAL PDF version of your Presentation and Brief to be uploaded to Turnitin by/before 10am on 10 November.

assessments.task_description:
Final Report

The Final Project Brief and Report is the main product of the research team’s efforts over the course of the year. The Final Project Brief and Report should be well structured and written to a high standard. The Report will include the 2-page Brief, the introduction to the research problem, aims and questions, literature, key concepts or theoretical framework, methodology, results, discussion and conclusion (with implications). Please ensure that all sources are appropriately evidenced and referenced including AI. Further task details and requirements (including relevant marking criteria) can be found in the relevant Assessment folder on Blackboard.

Project Progress Tasks

Group members will complete 10 project progress tasks/check-ins in weeks 1-12 (excluding interview and methods defence assessments on weeks 4 & 8) during class time and post individual responses to their team platform. Each project progress task/check-in requires team members to document their specific contributions, commit to deliverables for the following week, and assess group progress. All group members should complete the 10 project progress tasks to ensure consistent participation and prevent unequal workload distribution. Your contribution to the project progress tasks will be assessed by the course coordinator both during your in-class project work, and through the contributions you make on MS Teams during weeks 1-12 (excluding assessment weeks).  Each project progress task is worth .5 points for a total of 5 points towards your individual report mark.

Grading Impact: Individual final marks will be calculated as: Group Project Mark (max 40points) + .5 x each completed project progress task x 10 (= max 5 points) x PAF (via Buddycheck) = Individual Mark (max 45points).

Buddycheck: This assessment includes a Buddycheck. Each team member will complete a Buddycheck form by the due date which will provide an opportunity to reflect on the contribution each member of the team has made to the WHOLE group project. The Buddycheck form may be used to adjust marks according to contribution.
assessments.submission_guidelines: For the Final Report, only one member of your group is required to submit your assignment electronically by the due date and time.
